column1: thefilmstage 158372165406 "2017-03-14 00:00:45 GMT" http://blog.thefilmstage.com/post/158372165406/this-reminds-me-of-what-billy-wilder-once-said "“This reminds me of what Billy Wilder once said about Marilyn Monroe. Someone asked Billy Wilder how could he put up with Marilyn Monroe being late
column2: and doing all those things and not learning her lines and everything
column4: her name is Sadie. She can be on time
column6: she can be courteous and do all those things
column7: but when I put her in a movie no one would come and see her.’ This is a Terrence Malick film – so what else am I doing?” - producer Mike Medavoy on not getting involved in Malick’s process (via Terrence Malick: Rehearsing the Unexpected)" True text

column1: thefilmstage 157833425401 "2017-02-28 20:56:12 GMT" http://blog.thefilmstage.com/post/157833425401/moonlight-playwright-tarell-alvin-mccraney-and "“[Moonlight playwright Tarell Alvin McCraney] and I are this kid. We are Chiron. And you don’t think that kid grows up to be nominated for eight Academy Awards. It’s not a dream he’s allowed to have. I still feel that way. I didn’t think this was possible. But now I look at other people looking at me and if I didn’t think it was possible
column2: how are they going to? But now it’s happened. So what I think of possibility
column3: let’s take it off the table. The thing has happened.” - Barry Jenkins on the Best Picture acceptance speech he would have given." True text

column1: thefilmstage 154493567196 "2016-12-15 04:39:40 GMT" http://blog.thefilmstage.com/post/154493567196/andreii-tarkovsky-i-applaud-anyone-pointing-out "andreii-tarkovsky: i applaud anyone pointing out the lack of diversity in the film industry and trying to change that
column2: but maybe in the meantime actually watch films made by women and men of color… instead of just sit there and wait until the day hollywood gives a superhero movie to a director of color so you can pat yourself in the back while watching a marvel or dc movie while doing absolutely not changes yourself as an audience
column3: the bar can’t be so low that we eternally wait for these white producers to give us leftovers
column4: like let’s keep that discussion going until things improve but let’s watch as well the great films directed by women and men of color that already exist out there and we are not bothering to watch ‘cause they are not superhero movies. " False text

Francois Truffaut on Michelangelo Antonioni: “Antonioni is the only important director I have nothing good to say about. He bores me; he’s so solemn and humorless.” 2. column3: and Bunuel move in the same field as Tarkovsky. Antonioni was on his way
column5: suffocated by his own tediousness.” 3. Ingmar Berman on Orson Welles:“For me he’s just a hoax. It’s empty. It’s not interesting. It’s dead. Citizen Kane
column6: which I have a copy of — is all the critics’ darling
column7: always at the top of every poll taken
column8: but I think it’s a total bore. Above all
column9: the performances are worthless. The amount of respect that movie’s got is absolutely unbelievable.” 4. Ingmar Bergman on Jean-Luc Godard:“I’ve never gotten anything out of his movies. They have felt constructed
column11: and completely dead. Cinematographically uninteresting and infinitely boring. Godard is a fucking bore. He’s made his films for the critics. One of the movies
column14: was shot here in Sweden. It was mind-numbingly boring.” 5. Orson Welles on Jean-Luc Godard:“His gifts as a director are enormous. I just can’t take him very seriously as a thinker — and that’s where we seem to differ
column15: because he does. His message is what he cares about these days
column18: it could be written on the head of a pin.” 6. Werner Herzog on Jean-Luc Godard:“Someone like Jean-Luc Godard is for me intellectual counterfeit money when compared to a good kung-fu film.” 7. Jean-Luc Godard on Quentin Tarantino:“Tarantino named his production company after one of my films. He’d have done better to give me some money.” 8. Harmony Korine on Quentin Tarantino:“Quentin Tarantino seems to be too concerned with other films. I mean
column20: like in a blender. I think it’s
column22: really funny at the time I’m seeing it
column25: there’s a void there. Some of the references are flat
column26: just pop culture.” 9. Nick Broomfield on Quentin Tarantino:“It’s like watching a schoolboy’s fantasy of violence and sex
column27: which normally Quentin Tarantino would be wanking alone to in his bedroom while this mother is making his baked beans downstairs. Only this time he’s got Harvey Weinstein behind him and it’s on at a million screens.” 10. Spike Lee on Quentin Tarantino (and the “n-word” in his scripts):“I’m not against the word
column29: but not excessively. And some people speak that way. But
column30: Quentin is infatuated with that word. What does he want to be made — an honorary black man?” 11. Spike Lee on Tyler Perry:“We got a black president
column31: and we going back to Mantan Moreland and Sleep ‘n’ Eat?” 12. Tyler Perry on Spike Lee“Spike can go straight to hell! You can print that… Spike needs to shut the hell up!” 13. Clint Eastwood on Spike Lee:“A guy like him should shut his face.” 14. Jacques Rivette on Stanley Kubrick:“Kubrick is a machine
column33: a Martian. He has no human feeling whatsoever. But it’s great when the machine films other machines
column34: as in 2001.” 15. Jacques Rivette on James Cameron (and Steven Spielberg):“Cameron isn’t evil
column35: he’s not an asshole like Spielberg. He wants to be the new De Mille. Unfortunately
column36: he can’t direct his way out of a paper bag. “ 16. Jean-Luc Godard on Steven Spielberg:“I don’t know him personally. I don’t think his films are very good.” 17. Alex Cox on Steven Spielberg:“Spielberg isn’t a filmmaker
column37: he’s a confectioner.” 18. Tim Burton on Kevin Smith (after Smith jokingly accused Burton of stealing the ending of Planet of the Apes from a Smith comic book):“Anyone who knows me knows I would never read a comic book. And I would especially never read anything created by Kevin Smith.” 19. Kevin Smith on Tim Burton (in response to “I would never read a comic book”):“Which
column39: explains fucking Batman.” 20. Kevin Smith on Paul Thomas Anderson (specifically
column41: but I will keep it. I’ll keep it right on my desk
column42: as a constant reminder that a bloated sense of self-importance is the most unattractive quality in a person or their work.” 21. David Gordon Green on Kevin Smith:“He kind of created a Special Olympics for film. They just kind of lowered the standard. I’m sure their parents are proud; it’s just nothing I care to buy a ticket for.” 22. Vincent Gallo on Spike Jonze:“He’s the biggest fraud out there. If you bring him to a party he’s the least interesting person at the party
column43: he’s the person who doesn’t know anything. He’s the person who doesn’t say anything funny
column45: intelligent… He’s a pig piece of shit.” 23. Vincent Gallo on Martin Scorsese:“I wouldn’t work for Martin Scorsese for $10 million. He hasn’t made a good film in 25 years. I would never work with an egomaniac has-been.” 24. Vincent Gallo on Sofia (and Francis Ford) Coppola:“Sofia Coppola likes any guy who has what she wants. If she wants to be a photographer she’ll fuck a photographer. If she wants to be a filmmaker
column46: she’ll fuck a filmmaker. She’s a parasite just like her fat
column47: pig father was.” 25. Vincent Gallo on Abel Ferrara:“Abel Ferrara was on so much crack when I did The Funeral
column48: he was never on set. He was in my room trying to pick-pocket me.” 26. Werner Herzog on Abel Ferrara:“I have no idea who Abel Ferrara is. But let him fight the windmills… I’ve never seen a film by him. I have no idea who he is. Is he Italian? Is he French? Who is he?” 27. David Cronenberg on M. Night Shymalan:“I HATE that guy! Next question.” 28. Alan Parker on Peter Greenaway (specifically The Draughtsman’s Contact):“A load of posturing poo-poo.” 29. Ken Russell on Sir Richard Attenborough:“Sir Richard (‘I’m-going-to-attack-the-Establishment-fifty-years-after-it’s-dead’) Attenborough is guilty of caricature
column50: and repetition which all undermine the impact of the film.” 30. Uwe Boll on Michael Bay:“I’m not a fucking retard like Michael Bay.” x 31. Roy Andersson on Ingmar Bergman:“He’s made many movies — I think it’s over 50 — but not many of them are very good

column1: thefilmstage 71773885103 "2013-12-31 19:32:00 GMT" http://blog.thefilmstage.com/post/71773885103/the-top-50-non-2013-films-i-watched-for-the-first " I watched 378 films in 2013. Here’s the best new-to-me films I (Jordan Raup

column3: the ranking is mostly arbitrary. See my entire 2013 (to 2007) film log here. 50. The Big Heat 49. L'argent 48. The Ox-Bow Incident 47. From Here to Eternity 46. Ugetsu monogatari 45. Cries and Whispers 44. Spirit of the Beehive 43. The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie 42. The Devils 41. The Hidden Fortress 40. Children of Paradise 39. Viridiana 38. Yi Yi 37. Black Narcissus 36. Sansho the Bailiff 35. Crash 34. The Lost Weekend 33. Late Spring 32. Dracula 31. Sanjuro 30. The Young and the Damned 29. Nostalghia 28. The Exterminating Angel 27. Voyage to Italy 26. Hiroshima
column4: mon amour 25. The Cranes Are Flying 24. Beau travail 23. Come and See 22. Trouble In Paradise 21. Freaks 20. In a Lonely Place 19. Vivre sa vie 18. The Umbrellas of Cherbourg 17. Woman in the Dunes 16. F For Fake 15. Belle de jour 14. Jeanne Dielman
column7: 1080 Bruxelles 13. Army of Shadows 12. The Trial 11. Black Orpheus 10. A Man Escaped 9. The Conformist 8. Forbidden Games 7. Rome
column8: Open City 6. The Virgin Spring 5. The Crowd 4. A Matter of Life and Death 3. Harakiri 2. To Be or Not to Be 1. The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp What are your favorite films you watched for the first time in 2013?" True text
